summary.raw:
Automatically updated pinned apps when running fix_shortcuts()

Make fix_shortcuts() more cautious in deleting shortcuts, only deleting
a shortcut from the labscript suite install directory if it has a matching
entry in the start menu and has the name of one of the apps in it.

This makes it safer for code to call fix_shortcuts() automatically.
summary.html:
Automatically updated pinned apps when running fix_shortcuts()

Make fix_shortcuts() more cautious in deleting shortcuts, only deleting
a shortcut from the labscript suite install directory if it has a matching

This makes it safer for code to call fix_shortcuts() automatically.

values.message:
Automatically updated pinned apps when running fix_shortcuts()

Make fix_shortcuts() more cautious in deleting shortcuts, only deleting
a shortcut from the labscript suite install directory if it has a matching
entry in the start menu and has the name of one of the apps in it.

This makes it safer for code to call fix_shortcuts() automatically.

summary.raw:
Rename `labscript_suite_install_dir` to `labscript_suite_profile` (keeping the
old name as an alias for backward compatibility), since in the
upcoming restructuring, this will not be where the applications and libraries
are installed to, it will instead be the user's code, config and save data, and
app launchers, which we're calling a 'profile'.

Modify winshell functions to use the import path of each app instead of assuming
their locations within the profile directory (since they will not longer be
there in future).

Modify `versions._get_import_path()` to detect whether a package within the
`labscript_suite_profile` directory is a restructured repository with a
`setup.py`. If it is, then return the repository as the import
path, rather than the `labscript_suite_profile` directory.

This combined with 'shim' `__init__.py` and `__main__.py` files in restructured
packages to redirect imports and running `__main__.py` to the package one
directory down will allow these repositories to continue functioning as
previously even after they are restructured.

Minor version bump so that restructured packages can depend on the changed
functionality.

values.message:
Rename `labscript_suite_install_dir` to `labscript_suite_profile` (keeping the
old name as an alias for backward compatibility), since in the
upcoming restructuring, this will not be where the applications and libraries
are installed to, it will instead be the user's code, config and save data, and
app launchers, which we're calling a 'profile'.

Modify winshell functions to use the import path of each app instead of assuming
their locations within the profile directory (since they will not longer be
there in future).

Modify `versions._get_import_path()` to detect whether a package within the
`labscript_suite_profile` directory is a restructured repository with a
`setup.py`. If it is, then return the repository as the import
path, rather than the `labscript_suite_profile` directory.

This combined with 'shim' `__init__.py` and `__main__.py` files in restructured
packages to redirect imports and running `__main__.py` to the package one
directory down will allow these repositories to continue functioning as
previously even after they are restructured.

Minor version bump so that restructured packages can depend on the changed
functionality.
